question_text: Calculate the theoretical SO2 emission rate in g/kWh for a marine engine burning fuel with 2.5% sulfur content, assuming complete conversion of fuel sulfur to SO2, and explain how this changes with scrubber efficiency.
standard_answer: To calculate SO2 emissions, start with the fuel's sulfur content and energy basis. For marine fuels, typical lower heating value (LHV) is ~42 MJ/kg. Sulfur mass fraction: 2.5% = 0.025 kg S/kg fuel. Upon combustion, S + O2 → SO2, so molecular weights: S (32 g/mol) to SO2 (64 g/mol), giving a conversion factor of 64/32 = 2. Thus, SO2 produced per kg fuel = 0.025 kg S/kg fuel × 2 = 0.05 kg SO2/kg fuel. Energy input per kg fuel = 42 MJ. SO2 emission per MJ = 0.05 kg / 42 MJ = 0.00119 kg/MJ = 1.19 g/MJ. Convert to g/kWh: 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ, so SO2 = 1.19 g/MJ × 3.6 MJ/kWh = 4.28 g/kWh. This is the engine-out emission without control. With a scrubber of efficiency η (e.g., 99%), post-scrubber SO2 = 4.28 × (1 - η) g/kWh. For η=0.99, SO2 = 0.0428 g/kWh, demonstrating scrubbers' effectiveness even with high-sulfur fuels.
